description: The noun is derived from Middle English grandfadre, graundfadir, graunfadir, grauntfader, and other forms, from graunt (“big, large; great, important”) + fā̆der (“male parent, father; remoter male ancestor”), probably modelled after Middle French grandpere, grant pere (“male parent; remoter male ancestor”) (whence French grand-père); the English word is analysable as grand- +‎ father. Superseded earlier eldfather, elderfather.
The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: A father of someone's parent. [from 15th c.]
examples: Antonyms: (with regard to gender) grandmother, (with regard to ancestry) grandson; see also Thesaurus:grandmother

entries.meaning: (computing) The archived older version of a file that immediately preceded the father file.
examples: File C is the grandfather because it was used to create file B.

verbs.description: grandfather (third-person singular simple present grandfathers, present participle grandfathering, simple past and past participle grandfathered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be, or act as, a grandfather to.

description: From grandfather clause: see grandfather (etymology 1) and clause.

verbs.description: grandfather (third-person singular simple present grandfathers, present participle grandfathering, simple past and past participle grandfathered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly US, law) To retain discontinued laws or rules for (a thing, person or organization previously affected by them). [from 1950s]
